description:
This is a high-level overview of your Temporal cluster, helping you keep track of its global as well as service-wise health.

##### [**Datadog Temporal integration docs ↗**](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/temporal/)
title: Temporal Server Overview

definition.content:
This is a high-level overview of your Temporal cluster, helping you keep track of its global as well as service-wise health.

##### [**Datadog Temporal integration docs ↗**](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/temporal/)
These metrics provide a quick overview of the cluster's current status. They are expanded with more detail and with explanations further below.

Latencies experienced by all Temporal clients (including workers, CLI tools and anything that uses the Temporal API) for different operations.

`Poll` operations are excluded as they can be caused by no work being available and they time out after 1 minute.

definition.title: Average Frontend Latency by Operation (excluding poll operations)

definition.content:
Latency introduced by operations against the database, split by operations.

The database in a Temporal Cluster persists the Task Queues and Workflow Executions, among other data.
A high history cache latency might mean there are workflows starting too many activities or child workflows at the same time which could require restructuring.

This metric measures shard contention. [History shards](https://docs.temporal.io/clusters#history-shard) are critical for Workflow Execution throughput. A high value for this metric might mean that the number of shards needs to be scaled up.
Latency for indexing Workflow Executions in the Visibility backend. This is an indication of the time it takes for a workflow to show up in places like the UI and list filters.

When a new task is added in Temporal, one of two possible matching flows might occur, depending on whether there is already a worker waiting for tasks on the queue it is being added to.

If a worker is already waiting, then a *sync match* occurs and the task is sent directly to the worker without needing to persist it to the Task Queue. Otherwise, the task will be stored in the Task Queue and retrieved later when a worker polls for a new task.

These metrics present two complementary views into this process.

The Sync Match Rate is the percentage of matches that go through the *sync* workflow. A low value might indicate that adding more workers could be beneficial.

The amount of task creation requests reflect the number of tasks that follow the normal workflow and get persisted.

definition.title: Sync Match Rate (%) by Task Queue

definition.content: "Resource Exhausted" errors can indicate that the system is hitting RPS or QPS limits.
